title: Synthetic Recap
body:
HOUSTON – In an era defined by giants, one man stood so far above the rest he seemed to touch the heavens. It wasn't enough for the Minnesota Timberwolves to escape Houston with a 116-115 victory; they needed a supernova eruption from Kevin Garnett, who delivered a historic, career-defining performance that left the Compaq Center crowd in a state of awe-struck silence.

Garnett was not merely the best player on the floor; he was a force of nature, pouring in a career-high and franchise-record 47 points. He was unstoppable, operating with a ruthless efficiency from every corner of the court. The stat line—47 points, 12 rebounds, 6 assists, and 2 blocks—reads like a video game on the easiest setting, a complete dominance that left the Rockets scrambling for answers.

While the supporting casts dueled—Sam Mack’s 27 points for Houston, Tom Gugliotta’s 20 for Minnesota—the entire narrative orbited around Garnett’s gravity. Every possession was a question directed at The Big Ticket, and he had a devastating answer every time. His final points were the most critical, sealing the narrowest of victories for the Timberwolves in a game that felt far less close than the one-point margin suggested.

On this night, Garnett transcended the box score. He wasn't just a star; he was the game itself. The 47 points were a landmark, a declaration of his arrival among the league's absolute elite, and a performance that would be etched into Timberwolves lore forever.
